Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Test for local adaptation of recombination rate
Award.AbstractNarration:
Genetic recombination is fundamentally important to many genetic and evolutionary processes, including segregation, repair of double-strand breaks in DNA, removal of detrimental mutations, adaptation, and speciation. Prior research has shown that rates of gene recombination vary among individuals and populations, and are also modulated by temperature and other environmental factors in many species. Despite being the subject of over a hundred years of investigation, no study has tested the fundamental hypothesis of whether gene recombination rates exhibit adaptation to local environments. This project will examine variation in wild populations of the fruit fly, Drosophila pseudoobscura, and identify genomic regions undergoing rapid selection-driven evolution in recombination rates. This novel project is the first step in identifying the kind of natural selection that creates adaptation and species divergence in recombination rates. Additionally this project funds a partnership with a minority-serving high school and includes curriculum development to teach genetics in K-16 schools.

This project builds on decades of research on wild populations of Drosophila pseudoobscura to provide a critical "first-look" at whether recombination rates have adapted to local populations and potentially open the door to testing the nature of such adaptation. The primary goal of the proposed research will be to contrast variation within and between several natural populations of D. pseudoobscura in nucleotide sequence vs. recombination rate when tested in a constant environment. Significantly higher differentiation among populations in recombination rate would suggest that this phenotype has adapted to local environments, whereas lower differentiation in recombination rate would demonstrate that there has been broad stabilizing selection in this trait across the species range. The secondary goal of the research will be to test whether rates exhibited in nature are sometimes initially maladaptive in particular populations as a result of environmental modulation, and adaptation occurs within populations to mitigate the maladaptive rates induced by plasticity to the environment. Such "genetic compensation" has been inferred for other traits, but never suggested or tested with respect to recombination, despite its ubiquitous importance in inheritance, adaptation, and speciation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recombination is the exchange of genes between the two copies of a chromosome that an individual possesses (one from their father, one from their mother). Recombination happens along chromosomes in most animals and plants but at rates varying by sex, individual, and species. While we know variation in recombination rate exists among individuals, we do not know the proximate or evolutionary causes of this variation. Defects in or anomalous rates of recombination are also associated with disease. This project used the fruitfly Drosophila pseudoobscura to examine the proximate and evolutionary causes of recombination rate variation. Flies were sampled from two natural populations, inbred in the laboratory, and tested for their rates of recombination. The genomes of these flies were also sequenced to predict how much difference in recombination we should observe based on how much difference in DNA sequence exists among the populations.

 

We found extensive variation in recombination both within the two populations and between them. However, we detected very little difference in DNA sequence between the two populations, so the difference in recombination rate between the populations was greater than expected and may indicate that natural selection was involved. Recombination rates was strongly correlated across different chromosomes, implying much of the variation is affected by alleles with genome-wide effects rather than by localized effects. Consistent with that observation, we found no association between structural variation (e.g., chromosomal inversions, insertions, and deletions) and recombination rate. Finally, we showed that amino-acid-affecting nucleotide differences at three sites in recombination-associated genes were associated with a 5%-7% differences in recombination between lines.

 

Intellectual Merit: We have detected extensive variation in recombination rate at all scales, identified that the proximate causes of this variation are "global" recombination rate modifiers, and shown evidence that some of this variation may be driven by local adaptation. These are major advances in our understanding of a fundamental genetic process.

Broader Impacts: The scientific advances have potential implications for human health given that aberrant recombination is associated with disease. Further, a postdoctoral research associate and various students received extensive training in modern genomic skills (e.g., high-throughput genotyping-by-sequencing, working with PacBio long-read sequences) as well as project management and analysis, helping prepare them to enter the biomedical research workforce.
